questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter air tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from air tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks are equipped with drains that allow water and compressor oil to be removed from the system. If allowed to build up, water and compressor oil can damage an air brake system.

questions.question: What must be on an air tank in an air-braked vehicle?
questions.explanation: All air tanks on air-braked vehicles must have one-way check valves located between the air compressor and the first reservoir. This prevents air from flowing out in the event of a leak.

questions.question: How can you avoid becoming drowsy on a trip?
questions.answerA: Get about three hours of sleep beforehand.
questions.answerC: Do not build exercise into your daily routine.
questions.explanation: Strategies to reduce the risk of fatigue while driving include getting seven to eight hours of sleep beforehand; scheduling trips for the hours during which you are normally awake; planning to take breaks during the trip; and exercising regularly.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop. Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.

questions.question: A one-way check valve:
questions.answerA: Drains the water and compressor oil from the air tanks.
questions.answerB: Prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.answerC: Activates the emergency brakes when there is a leak.
questions.answerD: Holds the spring brakes in position until they are used.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: Emergency brakes:
questions.explanation: All trucks, truck tractors, and buses must be equipped with emergency brakes and parking brakes. These brakes must be held by mechanical force.

questions.question: To make it as safe as possible to leave a stop, you should park:
questions.answerA: So that you must back up to leave your parking space.
questions.answerB: So that you can pull forward to leave your parking space.
questions.answerC: On the side of a roadway, not in a parking lot.
questions.answerD: By backing into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Backing can be dangerous, so avoid doing it whenever you can. If possible, park in such a way that allows you to pull forward to exit your parking space.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: When making a turn, you do not need to:
questions.answerB: Cancel your turn signal after the turn.
questions.explanation: Be sure to activate the appropriate turn signal well in advance of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously throughout the turn and make sure to cancel the signal after the turn is completed, if your vehicle doesn't have self-canceling signals.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: In the event of a bus evacuation, students should be led at least ____ away from the road.
questions.explanation: If it is necessary to evacuate a school bus, students should be led by the driver in the direction of oncoming traffic to a safe location that is at least 100 feet off the road. This will help to ensure that they are not hit by flying debris if another vehicle hits the bus.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should generally:
questions.answerA: Stop between 15 and 50 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerB: Stop 100 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerC: Stop 10 feet before the nearest rail.
questions.answerD: Continue across the tracks without stopping.
questions.explanation: In general, school bus drivers should stop before any railroad crossings to check the tracks for approaching trains. Drivers should stop no closer than 15 feet, and no farther than 50 feet, from the nearest rail in order to have the best view of the tracks. They should look and listen for approaching trains before proceeding through the crossing.

questions.question: If exiting a bus during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must:
questions.answerA: Keep both hands on the handrail.
questions.answerC: Maintain a firm grasp on the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: A properly adjusted flat mirror should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The rear tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerC: Only the roadway and no parts of the bus.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted flat mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see 200 feet behind the bus, the base of each rear wheel, and the sides of the bus.

questions.question: During the steering box portion of the vehicle inspection test, you should not:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the steering box is securely mounted.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the steering box is free of leaks.
questions.answerC: Look for missing bolts in the steering box.
questions.answerD: Assume all cotter keys are present.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that the steering box is securely mounted. Check for missing nuts, bolts, and cotter keys. Be sure that there are no power steering fluid leaks and that there is no damage to power steering hoses.

questions.question: A school bus stop:
questions.answerA: Can be added by the driver if students are given notice of the change.
questions.answerB: Should be voted on by the students and parents.
questions.answerD: Should be established by the school and not changed.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should never change or add a stop without written approval from the appropriate school district officials.

questions.question: When taking the on-road test, you will be evaluated on regular traffic checks. You should not:
questions.answerC: Avoid checking your mirrors near intersections.
questions.explanation: While taking the on-road driving skills test, check for traffic and use your mirrors regularly, especially when encountering intersections. Scan and check for pedestrians in areas where they may be present.

questions.question: When exiting your vehicle, you must maintain ____ with the vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: During a vehicle inspection, ensure that the landing gear is:
questions.answerC: More worn on the passenger's side than on the driver's side.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a trailer during a vehicle inspection test, ensure that its landing gear has no missing parts and that it is fully raised. The crank handle should be secure and the support frame should not be damaged.

questions.question: If a school bus needs to be evacuated, passengers should:
questions.explanation: If a school bus needs to be evacuated in the event of an emergency, the driver must quickly determine which exit or exits will be safest for students to use and direct the students to that exit.

questions.question: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a placarded vehicle, you should always:
questions.answerB: Stop within five feet of the tracks.
questions.answerC: Change gears while on the tracks.
questions.answerD: Change lanes while on the tracks.
questions.explanation: If approaching a railroad crossing while driving a transit bus, school bus, or placarded vehicle, special procedures apply. Before crossing, stop your vehicle within 50 feet of, but not less than 15 feet from, the nearest rail. Activate your four-way flashers while crossing. Do not stop, change gears, or change lanes while any part of your vehicle is proceeding across the tracks.

questions.question: If the Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: You will not have any brakes.
questions.answerC: You should only use the parking brake to stop.
questions.answerD: You should stop driving and wait for the ABS to work again.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is in place as an addition to a braking system. It intervenes to prevent brakes from locking up during hard braking. If ABS is not working, the basic braking functions on a vehicle will still remain, so the driver can continue to drive and brake normally.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a school bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.answerD: Can be done with the driver talking to another driver.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading. The process must be properly supervised and done with care.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: Passive railroad crossings:
questions.answerD: Usually have a flagger directing traffic.
questions.explanation: Passive railroad crossings are not controlled by any traffic control devices. At such crossings, it is entirely a driver's responsibility to determine when it is safe to cross the tracks.

questions.question: During the on-road driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Develop your own route to show off your driving skills.
questions.answerB: Listen to directions from the examiner.
questions.answerC: Bring a passenger to ride with you.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, you must listen to and follow the directions given by the examiner. They will never ask you to drive in an unsafe manner.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, you may be asked to:
questions.answerA: Pull forward into a parking space.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: When asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.answerB: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull forward to the right, then back in a straight line.
questions.answerD: Pull forward to the left, then back in a straight line.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle control skills test, what is considered a look?
questions.answerA: Walking to the back of a vehicle to check its position
questions.answerB: Using side mirrors to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerC: Looking out of the driver's side window to check a vehicle's position
questions.answerD: A driver glancing over their shoulder to check blind spots
questions.explanation: A driver uses a look when they open their door, leave their seated position, and walk to the back of the vehicle to check its position. During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: When entering traffic on an expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerC: Abruptly enter a lane of traffic.
questions.answerD: Cut off other drivers if needed.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to enter an expressway. Before doing so, you must check traffic, use proper signals, and merge smoothly into the proper lane.

questions.question: When driving through a curve during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer from your lane if needed to complete the curve.
questions.answerB: Reduce your speed after entering the curve.
questions.answerC: Refrain from looking for other vehicles while turning.
questions.answerD: Reduce your speed before entering the curve.
questions.explanation: When approaching a curve during the on-road driving skills test, you must reduce your speed sufficiently before entering the curve so that you do not need to further brake or shift in the curve. Keep the vehicle in its lane and continue to check for traffic in all directions.

questions.question: An active railroad crossing:
questions.answerA: Has a traffic control device installed at the crossing.
questions.answerB: Does not have any traffic control devices installed at the crossing.
questions.answerC: Is characterized by having at least 10 vehicles cross the tracks every hour.
questions.explanation: Active railroad crossings use installed traffic control devices to regulate traffic. These devices can be in the form of flashing red lights, warning bells, and/or gates. The directions of devices controlling railroad crossings must always be followed.

questions.question: When performing the stop/start maneuver as a part of the skills test, you should:
questions.answerA: Cut off other vehicles if needed to get onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Slam on the brakes to stop as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be asked to pull your vehicle over to the side of the road and stop as if you were going to get out and check something on your vehicle. As you prepare to make this stop, you must check traffic; activate your turn signal; decelerate smoothly with even braking, changing gears as needed; and bring your vehicle to a full stop without coasting.

questions.question: The overhead inside rearview mirror:
questions.answerA: Allows the driver to see what is happening inside of the bus.
questions.answerB: Allows the driver to see what is happening outside of the bus.
questions.explanation: In a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: When alley docking, your vehicle should be parked:
questions.answerA: With the front bumper on top of the front boundary line.
questions.answerB: With the rear wheels over the rear boundary line.
questions.answerC: Straight within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.answerD: At an angle within the boundaries of the parking space.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to alley dock, you should first pull past the alley and stop your vehicle in a position that is parallel to the outer boundary. From there, you should back your vehicle entirely into the alley parking area. Your vehicle should be parked in a straight position within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Properly adjusted outside convex mirrors should allow the driver to see:
questions.answerA: The entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts.
questions.answerC: The rear door of the bus.
questions.explanation: On a school bus, outside convex mirrors should be adjusted to allow the driver to see at least one traffic lane on either side of the bus, the entire side of the bus up to the mirror mounts, and where the front of each rear tire touches the ground.

questions.question: If a bus is equipped with outside convex mirrors, they will be located:
questions.explanation: Outside convex mirrors on a school bus are located below the outside flat mirrors. They are used to see a wide view of traffic, clearance, and students around the bus.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you can acquire points by:
questions.answerC: Exiting the vehicle one time to check your positioning.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: In a school bus, where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door on the passenger side of the bus
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: On a school bus, the overhead inside rearview mirror is mounted directly above the windshield on the driver’s side of the bus. Its purpose is to allow the driver to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: After students unload at a school, the driver:
questions.answerA: May assume students have taken all of their belongings with them.
questions.answerB: Should assume the students have immediately cleared the doorway.
questions.answerC: Should walk through the bus and check for any sleeping or hiding students.
questions.answerD: May turn off the dispatch radio.
questions.explanation: After students have exited a bus at a school, the driver should walk through the bus to check for any remaining students who are hiding or sleeping. Drivers should also look out for items that students may have left behind.

questions.question: When checking tire condition during the vehicle inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that the insides of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerB: Ensure that the outsides of the tires are more worn than the insides of the tires.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the middles of the tires are more worn than the outsides of the tires.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the tires have even wear.
questions.explanation: When examining your tires during the vehicle inspection test, you should ensure that treads are evenly worn.

questions.question: As a general rule, student safety is best maintained by:
questions.answerA: Keeping the students on the bus.
questions.answerB: Letting some students evacuate the bus, while others stay on.
questions.explanation: In most emergency situations, students will be safest and best kept under control if they do not evacuate the school bus.

questions.question: When driving on the expressway during the skills test, you should:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to check traffic as needed.
questions.answerC: Drive on the left side of the lane.
questions.answerD: Drive above the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you may be asked to drive on an expressway. Make sure you maintain proper lane positioning, vehicle spacing, and vehicle speed. Continue to thoroughly check traffic in all directions while on the expressway.

questions.question: When taking the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. You should not:
questions.answerB: Select a gear that does not rev the engine.
questions.answerC: Forget to shift through an intersection.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving skills test, you will be evaluated on your gear usage. Select a gear that does not rev or lug the engine; avoid grinding and clashing gears; and avoid shifting through turns or intersections.

questions.question: During the pre-trip inspection test, you will be:
questions.answerA: Expected to explain your knowledge of the pre-trip process.
questions.answerB: Watching someone else check your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Watching a film on how to inspect a vehicle.
questions.answerD: Changing all the tires on your vehicle.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: A blind spot extends at least ____ behind a school bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus has blind spots immediately below the side flat mirrors, immediately in front of the side flat mirrors, and directly behind the rear bumper. Rear blind spots typically extend 50 to 150 feet behind a bus but can sometimes extend up to 400 feet, depending on the length of the vehicle.

questions.question: When students unload, they should:
questions.answerA: Remain seated until they are told to exit.
questions.answerB: Stand up and head toward the door while the bus is still moving.
questions.answerC: Exit the bus and stand next to the bus until it leaves.
questions.answerD: Jump down from the top step.
questions.explanation: Students leaving a school bus should remain seated until they are cleared to exit. After exiting, they should walk at least 10 feet away from the bus to a location where the driver can see them.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: Flammable gases are categorized as ____ hazards.
questions.explanation: Flammable gases are assigned to hazardous materials Class 2.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a shipping paper?
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle that contains hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: No other vehicles should be at the refueling station.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual contains all of the information needed to pass the written exam for a hazardous materials endorsement, it does not contain all of the information necessary to do the job safely. You can learn more by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the package must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages containing liquid containers should display arrows pointing in the correct upright direction. These packages should be placed facing the correct direction.

questions.question: If required, ____ identical placards must be placed on a vehicle.
questions.explanation: When hazardous materials placards are required, a vehicle must display four identical placards. A placard should be placed on the front, on the rear, and on both sides of the vehicle.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: A person should not smoke within ____ of a vehicle placarded for Class 3 or Division 2.1 materials.
questions.explanation: Do not smoke within 25 feet of a placarded cargo tank used to transport Class 3 or Division 2.1 hazardous materials.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerC: Does not need to know the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must be within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading of a tank with hazardous materials must always be watched by a qualified person. This person must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a background check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerD: A maximum of four feet tall.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials must be braced so that they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: Identification numbers assigned to chemicals can be found:
questions.answerA: In the DOT Emergency Response Guidebook.
questions.explanation: The United States Department of Transportation (DOT)’s Emergency Response Guidebook (ERG) lists all hazardous chemicals and their assigned identification numbers.

questions.question: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table contains:
questions.explanation: Column 2 of the Hazardous Materials Table lists the proper shipping names and descriptions of regulated materials.

questions.question: In general, when loading a tank with flammable liquids:
questions.answerB: A ground should be established before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerC: A ground should be broken right before opening the filling hole.
questions.answerD: The filling hole should be locked during loading.
questions.explanation: Before loading or unloading a tank with flammable liquids, you should turn off the engine, unless running the engine is necessary to operate a pump. Ground the tank before opening the filling hole and maintain the ground until after closing the filling hole.

questions.question: Who is responsible for installing placards on a vehicle?
questions.explanation: While shippers of hazardous materials are responsible for providing necessary placards, it is the driver's responsibility to actually place them on the vehicle.

questions.question: The person loading a tank with hazardous materials must be all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Aware of the hazards associated with the materials.
questions.explanation: The person in charge of loading or unloading a hazardous materials cargo tank must ensure that a qualified person is always supervising the process. The supervisor must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; be within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the involved materials; know the procedures to follow in the case of an emergency; and be authorized to and capable of moving the tank.

questions.question: Regulations relating to hazardous materials are intended to protect:
questions.explanation: Transporting hazardous materials can be risky. The regulations are intended to protect you, those around you, and the environment.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: If transporting explosives:
questions.answerA: You must have a written route plan.
questions.answerB: You should take the shortest route.
questions.explanation: When transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you must have a written route plan and follow that plan. Whenever possible, avoid heavily populated areas, crowds, tunnels, narrow streets, and alleys.

questions.question: How must a shipper notify a driver of the risks associated with their cargo?
questions.answerB: By writing a note on a blank piece of paper
questions.answerC: By putting hazard warning labels on packages
questions.answerD: By placing orange dots on packages
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous cargo must alert drivers and others to relevant hazards through proper shipping papers, hazard warning labels on packages, emergency response information, and placards.

questions.question: If you notice hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.answerD: Drive around looking for a person to repair the leak.
questions.explanation: If a cargo leak develops while you are carrying hazardous materials, do not continue driving any farther than safety requires. The farther you drive, the larger the contaminated area will become. You should park the vehicle, secure the area, and stay with the vehicle while sending someone else to get help.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: There may be restrictions on the transportation of explosives or hazardous waste in certain areas. These restrictions:
questions.answerC: Should be researched before taking a route.
questions.answerD: Only apply if transporting more than 1,000 pounds of a material.
questions.explanation: Before transporting hazardous materials, you should research any restrictions that may apply to the routes you plan to take.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be placed in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on its side.
questions.answerD: The package should be made of wood.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper, which placard must be displayed?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: Who must provide emergency response information?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to provide emergency response information to drivers.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.explanation: Containers of corrosive materials should be kept in their correct upright positions. They should not be dropped or rolled.

questions.question: Emergency response information provided by the shipper must include:
questions.answerA: Any risks of fire or explosion.
questions.answerD: How many people should respond in the event of an accident.
questions.explanation: At a minimum, emergency response information must include the basic descriptions and technical names of the materials being transported; immediate hazards to health; risks of fire or explosion; immediate precautions to be taken in the event of an accident or incident; immediate methods for handling fires; initial methods for handling spills or leaks in the absence of fires; and preliminary first aid measures.

questions.question: A driver needs a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to transport hazardous materials in:
questions.answerA: A vehicle requiring a Class A license.
questions.answerB: A vehicle requiring a Class B license.
questions.answerC: A vehicle requiring a Class C license.
questions.explanation: You must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement to operate a vehicle of any size to transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an acceptable location to keep hazardous materials' shipping papers?
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driver’s side door
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passenger’s side door
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened
questions.answerD: On the driver’s seat while the driver is outside of the vehicle
questions.explanation: When the vehicle is being driven, hazardous materials' shipping papers must be kept in a pouch on the driver's door or somewhere else that is in clear view and within the driver's reach. If the driver is outside of the vehicle, the shipping papers should be kept on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If a leak is suspected in a cargo of radioactive material:
questions.answerA: The driver should go to the local fire department.
questions.answerB: The driver should pick up any loose pieces of the radioactive material.
questions.answerC: The driver should continue to carry the cargo, as long as they avoid touching the affected areas.
questions.answerD: The driver should not operate the vehicle until it has been cleaned.
questions.explanation: If you are transporting radioactive material and believe there is a leak or broken package in your cargo, you should tell your dispatcher or supervisor as quickly as possible. Do not touch or inhale the material. Do not use the vehicle until it has been cleaned or checked with a survey meter.

questions.question: Who is responsible for identifying the hazard class of a hazardous material?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for using the hazardous materials regulations to determine the product's identification number, proper shipping name, hazard class, and packing group. They are also responsible for determining the correct packaging, labels, markings, and placards to use.

questions.question: Unless it is clearly unsafe, what does a driver need to accept a package?
questions.explanation: When the shipper packages hazardous materials, they certify that the package has been prepared according to Hazardous Materials Regulations (HMR). Unless a package is clearly unsafe or noncomplying with HMR, you may accept the shipper’s certification concerning the proper packaging of a material.

questions.question: Your engine runs a pump used during the delivery of compressed gas. After delivery, you should turn off the engine ____ unhooking the hoses.
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: If a box contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials packages with containers of liquid inside must have orientation markings with arrows pointing in the direction that should be upright.

questions.question: Which agency helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards?
questions.answerC: The United Center for Chemical Assistance
questions.explanation: As a resource to police and firefighters, the National Response Center helps coordinate emergency response to chemical hazards.

questions.question: What can be a clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials?
questions.answerA: The shipper is a business you might expect to deal with hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.answerD: The road is made of gravel.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that you would expect to involve hazardous materials. Examples of such businesses include paint dealers, chemical suppliers, scientific supply houses, pest control companies, agricultural suppliers, and dealers in explosives, fireworks, or munitions.

questions.question: What does a hazardous materials shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: A shipping paper describes the hazardous materials being transported. Shipping orders, bills of lading, and manifests are all shipping papers.

questions.question: What does "RQ" stand for?
questions.explanation: When marking hazardous materials in an "HM" column on a shipping paper, the letters "RQ" may be used instead of an "X" if a reportable quantity of the material must be identified.

questions.question: What shape is a placard indicating hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.answerD: A maximum of four feet tall.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials must be braced so that they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle that contains hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.answerD: No other vehicles should be at the refueling station.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: How many hazardous materials classes are there?
questions.explanation: There are nine different classes of hazardous materials. A class reflects the risks associated with a type of material.

questions.question: Materials that are considered hazardous may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials are products that pose risks to health, safety, and property during transportation. Materials that are considered hazardous include explosives; flammable and poisonous gases; and flammable and other hazardous solids.

questions.question: Shippers must keep a copy of shipping papers for:
questions.explanation: Shippers must retain a physical copy or an electronic image of hazardous materials shipping papers for a minimum of two years after the materials are accepted by the initial carrier. For hazardous waste, this increases to three years.

questions.question: Class 1, Class 2.1, and Class 3 items should not be placed in a trailer with:
questions.explanation: The use of cargo heaters is not always permitted. When transporting materials that are categorized as Class 1 (Explosives), Class 2.1 (Flammable Gas), or Class 3 (Flammable Liquids) materials, heaters are generally prohibited.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You can proceed without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.answerD: You can proceed without stopping if no other vehicles are within sight.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: The identification number associated with a hazardous material should appear:
questions.answerD: On a bumper sticker on the vehicle.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It must also appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: The only way to properly check tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tire with your hand.
questions.answerD: Measuring the height of the tire.
questions.explanation: You should examine your tires at the beginning of every trip and after every stop to ensure that they are properly inflated. The only acceptable way to check tire pressure is to use a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: On a shipping paper, if the letter “G” appears in Column 1, what else needs to appear?
questions.answerA: The technical name of the hazardous material
questions.answerB: The type of packaging containing the hazardous material
questions.answerD: The date the product was packed
questions.explanation: If the letter “G,” for "Generic," is written in Column 1 of a shipping paper, the technical name of the associated hazardous material must also be listed.

questions.question: If you notice hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerB: Park the vehicle as soon as possible.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.answerD: Drive around looking for a person to repair the leak.
questions.explanation: If a cargo leak develops while you are carrying hazardous materials, do not continue driving any farther than safety requires. The farther you drive, the larger the contaminated area will become. You should park the vehicle, secure the area, and stay with the vehicle while sending someone else to get help.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials should always be loaded away from heat sources. Many materials become more hazardous if their temperatures increase.

questions.question: A material’s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: The amount of packaging required to make the shipment.
questions.answerC: The location on the trailer where items may be placed.
questions.answerD: How the material should be loaded and unloaded.
questions.explanation: There are nine different hazard classes. A material's hazard class reflects its associated risks.

questions.question: If you apply for a HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain an original or renewed hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a Transportation Security Administration (TSA) background check.

questions.question: Shippers must label hazardous materials. If an item is smaller than its label, how should the item be labeled?
questions.answerA: The item may be tied together with other hazardous materials and labeled with a sheet of paper on the outside of the bundle.
questions.answerB: The label may be attached to a tag that is securely attached to the package.
questions.answerC: The item may be marked with a large orange dot.
questions.answerD: The item may be placed in a box displaying a warning label.
questions.explanation: Shippers must place diamond-shaped hazard warning labels on most packages of hazardous materials. If the label won't fit on the package, it can be placed on a tag that is securely attached to the package.

questions.question: How does doubling your speed from 20 mph to 40 mph affect your vehicle's braking distance?
questions.explanation: Increasing your vehicle's speed will increase your vehicle's striking power and braking distance. Doubling your vehicle's speed from 20 to 40 mph will multiply its braking distance by four.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when:
questions.answerA: A truck driver is driving too fast.
questions.answerB: The driver of a vehicle in front of a truck is moving to slowly.
questions.answerC: A truck driver is driving too slowly.
questions.explanation: Rollovers happen when a vehicle is driven too fast. To reduce the risk of rollover, make sure the weight of cargo is loaded low to the ground, and that you take turns and curves slowly.

questions.question: What is the minimum permitted size of a placard?
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials must be diamond-shaped and a size of at least 10 ¾ square inches.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tank.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and compressor oil from the air tank.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks must be drained to remove accumulated water and compressor oil. Failing to do so can cause damage. Manually operated drains should be used at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: When using road speed to know when to switch gears, you should:
questions.answerA: Learn what speeds each gear is good for and shift up when necessary.
questions.answerB: Watch other vehicles and try to keep pace.
questions.answerC: Watch other trucks and shift when they shift.
questions.answerD: Use the speed limit as a guide.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When uncoupling a dolly, you should:
questions.answerA: Unlock the pintle hook before moving the dolly out from under the rear trailer.
questions.answerB: Move the dolly out from under the rear trailer before unlocking the pintle hook.
questions.answerD: Remove the dolly as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: Never unlock the pintle hook with the dolly still under the rear trailer. This could cause the dolly tow bar to fly up, possibly causing serious injury.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.answerD: Drive faster than the posted speed limit.
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road to spot potential hazards in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards if they become dangerous.

questions.question: When backing, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the passenger’s side mirror.
questions.answerC: Turn toward the passenger’s side whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in reverse, you should back up slowly and use the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle. Use a helper to monitor your blind spots whenever possible. You and the helper should agree on a signal for "stop."

questions.question: Which of the following is not a problem?
questions.answerC: Exhaust parts rubbing against fuel system parts
questions.answerD: Exhaust system parts that are not leaking
questions.explanation: When inspecting an exhaust system, you should verify that parts of the system are not loose, broken, or missing. The system's parts must be properly mounted and should not be rubbing against moving parts of the vehicle.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a triple combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A triple combination should have a leakage rate no higher than 6 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The service line, also called the control line or signal line, carries air to the trailer brakes and is controlled by the foot brake or trailer hand brake.

questions.question: When doing an inspection, make sure your brake pads are:
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.explanation: The parking brake in a vehicle with air brakes should be used every time the vehicle is parked.

questions.question: Fully-loaded rigs:
questions.answerA: Are less likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerB: Are more likely to roll over than empty rigs.
questions.answerC: Are just as likely to roll over as empty rigs.
questions.explanation: Because the weight of cargo gives them a higher center of gravity, fully-loaded rigs are 10 times more likely to roll over in a crash than empty rigs.

questions.question: You must put out emergency warning devices within ____ of stopping on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the shoulder of a road, put out your emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping. When pulling off the road to stop, be sure to turn on your four-way emergency flashers.

questions.question: When checking your mirrors:
questions.answerA: Do not use the passenger side mirror.
questions.answerB: Do not use the driver's side mirror.
questions.answerD: Look in each mirror for long stretches of time.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Check all mirrors frequently while driving.

questions.question: If involved in a crash, basic procedures should include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: If you are involved in a crash, the three basic things you need to do are protect the area, notify the proper authorities, and care for anyone injured. It is important to protect the accident site immediately after the accident occurs to help prevent another crash from happening in the same location.

questions.question: Which of the following types of vehicles is most prone to the “crack-the-whip" effect?
questions.explanation: Double and triple combinations are the most vulnerable to turning over as a result of the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: To check the automatic transmission fluid level in some vehicles, the vehicle:
questions.answerD: May have to be left running.
questions.explanation: For some vehicles, you may need to leave the engine running to be able to check its automatic transmission fluid level.

questions.question: When using a turn signal, you should not:
questions.answerC: Cancel the turn signal after completing the turn.
questions.answerD: Allow the turn signal to stay on long after the turn has been completed.
questions.explanation: Always signal well ahead of a turn or lane change. Signal continuously until you have completed the turn or lane change, then be sure to cancel the signal so you do not confuse other drivers.

questions.question: Hydroplaning usually occurs:
questions.answerC: In areas where water collects on the road.
questions.explanation: In places where water collects on the road, it is possible for a vehicle to hydroplane. Low tire pressure or worn tire tread makes this more likely to happen. If there is enough water on a road surface, hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: What is the only way to sober up after drinking?
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be increased through tricks like drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to wait for the alcohol to be removed from your system.

questions.question: Check ____ to ensure that the air in your vehicle's air braking system flows to all tires.
questions.explanation: Check the air brakes on a double or triple combination during your normal pre-trip inspection. After air pressure has reached a normal level, push in the red trailer air supply knob to send air to the emergency lines. Use the trailer hand brake to send air to the service line, then open the rear shut-off valve. If air is escaping through the valve, you will know that the entire system is charged.

questions.question: If a truck's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is not working:
questions.answerA: The truck will not have any brakes.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven only at slow speeds.
questions.answerC: The truck will still have brakes.
questions.answerD: The truck will lack brakes on its left side.
questions.explanation: If an ABS system fails, the vehicle will still have normal braking function. The driver should continue to drive and brake as they normally would.

questions.question: Before a vehicle with dual air brakes is driven, pressure of at least ____ should be built up in both braking systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up pressure of at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: The air pressure in a dual air brake system should build from 85 to 100 psi within:
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: After the engine is started, warning lights and buzzers should all:
questions.answerD: Turn off once the vehicle begins moving.
questions.explanation: After the engine is started, the warning lights and buzzers should deactivate immediately. The charging circuit warning, oil, coolant, and Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) lights should all turn off.

questions.question: What is the average driver’s reaction time?
questions.answerC: Between three-quarters of a second and one second
questions.explanation: The average driver has a reaction time of between three-quarters of a second and one second.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indication of damaged brakes?
questions.answerB: Shoes with oil or grease on them
questions.answerD: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: Potential problems to check for when inspecting brakes include cracked drums; shoes or pads with oil, grease, or brake fluid on them; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection:
questions.answerB: Is helpful in identifying minor issues before they become major problems.
questions.answerC: Should not be done by the driver.
questions.answerD: Should be performed once a month.
questions.explanation: A vehicle should be inspected before every trip to help ensure that any small mechanical issues are caught before they become more serious problems. It is better to discover a problem with your vehicle before a drive than after the drive has begun.

questions.question: A vehicle inspection:
questions.answerA: Should only be performed once a week.
questions.answerB: Should not be done unless the driver feels qualified to perform the inspection.
questions.answerC: Should be performed by a friend to the driver.
questions.answerD: Should be performed before every trip.
questions.explanation: To ensure its safe operation, a vehicle should be inspected by every driver before every trip.

questions.question: With your low beam headlights turned on, you should be able to see about ____ ahead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Low beam headlights allow you to see about 250 feet ahead of your vehicle. When driving at night, adjust your speed so that you will be able to stop in the distance illuminated by your headlights.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a fire?
questions.explanation: Possible causes of vehicle fires include spilled fuel or improper use of flares following an crash; under-inflated tires or dual tires that touch; short circuits in the electrical system; smoking around fuel; improper fueling or loose fuel connections; and carrying cargo that is flammable, improperly sealed or loaded, or poorly ventilated.

questions.question: When driving, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Keep your attention focused in front of your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Look only to the front and right side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Look only to the front and sides of your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Look to the front, sides, and rear of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle. In addition to watching the road ahead, you should frequently check your mirrors to monitor the road to the sides and to the rear of your vehicle.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.explanation: When passing a pedestrian or another vehicle, you should assume that they don't see you.

questions.question: To release a dolly's air brakes before positioning the converter dolly for coupling, you should:
questions.answerA: Remove the dolly parking brake control.
questions.explanation: If a converter dolly has air brakes, you can release the brakes by opening the dolly air tank petcock. Releasing the dolly's brakes is the first step you should take when properly positioning the dolly in front of the rear trailer.

questions.question: To prevent fatigue while driving, you should:
questions.explanation: A hot, poorly-ventilated area can make a person sleepy. Opening a window, opening a vent, or using the air conditioning can help keep the cab cool and reduce the risk of fatigue.

questions.question: If one air system in a dual air brake system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully.
questions.answerC: There will be no noticeable affect.
questions.answerD: Lights on the outside of the tractor will flash.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, if one of the air systems gets very low on pressure, either the front or rear brakes will not be operating fully. You should bring your vehicle to a safe stop and have the air system repaired.

questions.question: A person supervising the loading of a tank:
questions.answerA: Does not have to be able to move the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Does not need to know about the materials being loaded.
questions.answerD: Must stay within 25 feet of the tank.
questions.explanation: The loading and unloading of a tank must be watched by a qualified person. They must be alert; have a clear view of the tank; stay within 25 feet of the tank; know the hazards of the materials involved; know the procedures to follow in an emergency; and be authorized and able to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: The only way to properly check your tire pressure is by:
questions.answerC: Pushing on the tires to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: When other vehicles have trouble seeing you at dawn or dusk, you can increase your visibility by:
questions.explanation: At dawn or dusk, and in snowy or rainy conditions, you should turn on your headlights to make it easier for other road users to see your vehicle.

questions.question: Generally, a shipping paper must list:
questions.answerC: The location of fire departments along the planned route.
questions.explanation: In general, a shipper is required to list an emergency response telephone number on hazardous materials' shipping papers. There are some exceptions to this rule.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Headlights should be turned off during the day.
questions.answerC: Headlights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Headlights should only be used in the rain.
questions.explanation: When driving at night, it is important that your lights be clean so that they provide as much light as possible. This will help others to see your vehicle.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: If there is open space in the truck.
questions.answerC: If the amount of hazardous materials in the truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.answerD: If the hazardous materials create an inhalation hazard.
questions.explanation: Placards must be placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. They identify the specific class or classes of materials being carried and warn others of relevant hazards.

questions.question: A person working on a disabled vehicle on the shoulder of a road:
questions.answerA: Will likely pay attention to traffic on the road.
questions.answerB: May be focused on the repair and not paying attention to roadway traffic.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on disabled vehicles. The task will likely consume their attention, so they may not be aware of traffic or other hazards on the road.

questions.question: The controlled braking method is:
questions.answerA: When the driver locks the wheels and steers.
questions.answerB: When the driver uses the brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.answerC: When the driver only slightly taps the brakes.
questions.answerD: When the driver downshifts the gears to brake.
questions.explanation: The method of controlled braking involves applying the brakes as hard as you can without locking the wheels. If you need to make large steering adjustments while using controlled braking, you should remove your foot from the brake pedal, steer, then reapply the brakes.

questions.question: ____ is a thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. This makes the road look as if it is merely wet.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead of you, you should:
questions.answerA: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the driver’s aggressive behavior to the police.
questions.answerC: Continue driving and mind your own business.
questions.answerD: Pull over and yell at the driver.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: Tanks usually have:
questions.explanation: Driving tank vehicles requires special care because they have high centers of gravity. Drivers should be particularly aware of their speeds when operating in turns and curves

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) will:
questions.answerA: Allow you to drive faster than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerB: Allow you to follow other vehicles more closely than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.answerC: Allow you to drive less carefully than you would be able to otherwise.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) will help you to maintain control during hard braking. ABS will not necessarily shorten your stopping distance.

questions.question: A convex mirror is sometimes called a ____ mirror.
questions.explanation: Large vehicles often have curved, convex mirrors, sometimes referred to as "fisheye," "spot," or "bug-eye" mirrors. These mirrors provide a wider view than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they actually are.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a tire problem to check for and avoid?
questions.answerA: Radial and bias-ply tires used together
questions.answerB: Recapped tires on the front of a school bus
questions.answerD: All tires are made by the same company
questions.explanation: During an inspection, there are a number of tire problems to check for and avoid. Look for air pressure that is too low or too high; excessive wear; cuts or other damage; tread separation; dual tires that come into contact with each other or other parts of the vehicle; mismatched tire sizes; radial and bias-ply tires used together; cut or cracked valve stems; and regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires on the front wheels of a school bus.

questions.question: Stopping distance can be affected by:
questions.explanation: Stopping distance is affected by a vehicle's speed. The faster you are driving, the longer your stopping distance will become.

questions.question: Placards must be placed:
questions.answerA: In any manner, as long as they are visible.
questions.answerB: So words and numbers are read from left to right.
questions.answerD: Within three inches of other markings.
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials placards must be positioned so any words or numbers can be read from left to right. They must be at least three inches away from any other markings.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver confronts you, you should not:
questions.answerD: Try to get out of their way.
questions.explanation: When confronted with an aggressive driver, your first priority should be to get out of their way. Do not provoke the driver by making eye contact, trying to race, or refusing to move out of your traffic lane. Additionally, ignore any gestures that are intended to provoke you.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be placed in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on its side.
questions.answerD: The package should be made of wood.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: Manhole covers should:
questions.explanation: To ensure that a tank will not leak in transit, check its manhole covers and vents. Make sure that the covers have gaskets and that they close correctly.

questions.question: A driver should always:
questions.explanation: While driving, you should continually scan the road ahead to spot potential hazards well in advance. Make emergency plans for how to deal with the hazards in the event that they become dangerous.

questions.question: If transporting explosives, you may leave your vehicle unattended:
questions.explanation: When transporting hazardous materials, you may leave your vehicle unattended in a safe haven. A safe haven is a location that has been approved for parking unattended vehicles that are loaded with explosives.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop. Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.

questions.question: When an engine is started:
questions.answerA: The brakes should be locked up.
questions.answerB: Warning lights should come on and then quickly turn off.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: Proper coupling technique:
questions.answerA: Is the same on all vehicles.
questions.answerB: Is essential to the safe operation of a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Includes ensuring that the fifth wheel plate is not greased.
questions.explanation: Knowing proper coupling and uncoupling technique is fundamental to the safe operation of combination vehicles. Improper coupling can be very dangerous.

questions.question: If you’re feeling tired before a drive, you should:
questions.answerD: Drive as fast as possible so you get to the destination quickly.
questions.explanation: Stimulant drugs, including caffeine, are not helpful as a way of avoiding fatigue. They may help keep you awake, but will not make you any more alert. Feeling tired is a sign that your body needs sleep, and the only way to properly address it is to stop driving and get some sleep.

questions.question: If an aggressive driver is involved in a crash on the road ahead of you, you should:
questions.answerA: Block the driver in with your vehicle.
questions.answerB: Stop after the crash scene and report the driver’s aggressive behavior to the police.
questions.answerC: Continue driving and mind your own business.
questions.answerD: Pull over and yell at the driver.
questions.explanation: If you observe a crash involving an aggressive driver, you should stop a safe distance from the crash scene, wait for police to arrive, and inform them of the aggressive behavior you witnessed.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day. It is more difficult for drivers to see hazards, the glare of headlights can affect drivers' vision, and there are more fatigued and impaired drivers on the road.

questions.question: When checking a tank vehicle, it is most important to verify that:
questions.answerB: There is no frost on the windshield.
questions.explanation: A tank vehicle has a number of items that must be checked during a pre-trip inspection. Refer to the operator's manual for your specific vehicle to ensure that you are checking the vehicle properly. When inspecting any tank vehicle, it is most important to verify that there are no leaks.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: When checking your vehicle's lights before driving:
questions.answerA: The vehicle should be running and in gear.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The check can be done from inside the vehicle.
questions.answerD: The check can be done by looking at a reflection from a shiny surface.
questions.explanation: To check your vehicle's lights before a trip, you should set the parking brake, turn off the engine, remove the key from the ignition, and take the key with you. Turn on your low beam headlights and four-way flashers. Get out of the vehicle to make sure the lights are working properly.

questions.question: If you apply for an original or renewal HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a check through which agency?
questions.explanation: To obtain a hazardous materials endorsement, you must pass a security check conducted by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: To know which placards to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard classes of the materials.
questions.answerB: The types of containers holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which hazardous materials placards to use, you must know the hazard class of the materials; the amount of hazardous materials being shipped; and the total weight of all classes of hazardous materials in the vehicle.

questions.question: To help your vehicle be seen by others:
questions.answerB: Your headlights should be turned off during the day.
questions.answerC: Your headlights should be covered with grease.
questions.answerD: Your headlights should be used, but only in the rain.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's headlights should be clean during trips. This will ensure that the lights can provide as much light as possible, helping the vehicle to be seen.

questions.question: Pull out the trailer air supply control to test:
questions.explanation: Be sure to test the trailer emergency brakes before beginning a trip. After ensuring that the trailer rolls freely, you can test the emergency brakes by pulling out the trailer air supply control, or placing it in the "emergency" position. Pull forward slightly with the tractor and make sure the trailer does not move.

questions.question: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, what letters will appear on the shipping paper and package?
questions.explanation: If a substance is being transported in a reportable quantity, the shipper must display the letters "RQ" on the shipping paper and package.

questions.question: To test the trailer service brakes, you should:
questions.answerA: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.answerC: Reverse the vehicle slowly and apply the brakes with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control.
questions.explanation: To test the trailer service brakes, you should first ensure that the braking system has a normal air pressure level, then release the parking brake. You should then move the vehicle forward slowly and apply the brakes with the hand control. If the trailer service brakes are working properly, you will feel the brakes activate.

questions.question: What should you do if the coolant temperature gauge rises above the highest safe temperature?
questions.answerB: Pull over and find out what the problem is.
questions.explanation: A coolant gauge rising above the highest safe temperature may indicate that there is a problem with the vehicle that could result in engine failure or a fire in the engine. Stop as soon as you safely can and investigate the problem.

questions.question: Which cargo is the most difficult to transport, due to its shifting weight?
