questions.explanation: Driving with liquids in a partially-filled tank requires special care because liquids are prone to surge when carried in a tank. Liquid surge causes a vehicle's weight to shift.

questions.question: The easiest way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is to:
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors to determine if the trailer has left the lane.
questions.answerC: Release the brake pedal and then push it down again.
questions.answerD: Watch the jackknife warning light on the control panel.
questions.explanation: The easiest way to spot a trailer skid is to use your mirrors. Any time you brake hard, check your mirrors to ensure that your trailer is still in its proper position.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Check the wear of the tire.
questions.answerC: Check the level of windshield wiper fluid.
questions.answerD: Check the air pressure of the tire.
questions.explanation: After a tire is changed, you should stop after a short distance to ensure that the lug nuts are still safely in place.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerA: At a rate that changes depending on how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerB: At a consistent rate, regardless of how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person drinks coffee.
questions.answerD: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be accelerated through common tricks, such as drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it requires to process the alcohol out of your system.

questions.question: If driving a charter bus, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Tell passengers how to operate the TVs, if equipped.
questions.answerB: Not allow passengers to board until the scheduled departure time.
questions.answerC: Allow passengers to board early to get ahead of schedule.
questions.answerD: Tell passengers to fill the back of the bus first.
questions.explanation: To help prevent theft or vandalism, charter bus drivers should not allow passengers to board the vehicle until the scheduled departure time.

questions.question: Baggage and freight should be stored in a way that:
questions.answerA: Allows riders to exit by any door or window in an emergency.
questions.answerB: Blocks an exit, if at least one other exit is available to passengers.
questions.answerC: Partially covers a door, since the items can be moved aside.
questions.answerD: Allows the cargo to be easily offloaded in an emergency.
questions.explanation: On a bus, all baggage and freight should be stored in a manner that allows the driver to move freely and easily; allows riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency; and protects riders from injury if items fall or shift.

questions.question: Bent lock rings:
questions.answerB: Are not a concern in dry weather.
questions.explanation: Mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings are dangerous and should not be used.

questions.question: A vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) can be identified by:
questions.answerA: A sticker on the control panel.
questions.answerB: A yellow lamp on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: The letters "ABS" on the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: A metal plate on the inside of the driver’s side door.
questions.explanation: You can tell that your vehicle is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) if it has a yellow ABS malfunction lamp on the instrument panel.

questions.question: If driving a school bus, your four-way flashers should:
questions.answerA: Be activated before crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Only be used after crossing railroad tracks.
questions.answerD: Only be used near railroad tracks if a train is approaching.
questions.explanation: When driving a school bus, you must activate your four-way flashers while approaching and crossing a railroad crossing. Deactivate the flashers once your entire vehicle has cleared the tracks.

questions.question: If you are turning left and there are two available left turn lanes, which lane should you choose?
questions.answerD: Trucks should not turn where there are two left turn lanes.
questions.explanation: A large vehicle may need to swing right to make a left turn. If an intersection has two left turn lanes, the driver should choose the righthand land to begin their turn.

questions.question: When checking the springs during a vehicle inspection, do all of the following, except:
questions.answerC: Ensure torsion springs are not damaged.
questions.explanation: When checking the springs as part of the vehicle inspection test, you should look for missing, shifted, cracked, or broken leaf springs, as well as broken or distorted coil springs. If the vehicle is equipped with torsion bars, torque arms, or other types of suspension components, ensure that they are not damaged and are mounted securely.

questions.question: Suspension system defects may include all of the following, except:
questions.explanation: Defects to check for when inspecting your vehicle's suspension system include cracked or broken spring hangers; missing or broken leaves in a leaf spring; and leaking shock absorbers. If you spot any of these issues, be sure to have them repaired.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle, you should:
questions.explanation: You should always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle.

questions.question: When traction is poor, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is best to always accelerate very slowly.
questions.answerB: So they do not lose control of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: So the driver does not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerD: To be the last vehicle through an intersection.
questions.explanation: Speeding up too quickly on a road with poor traction could cause a driver to lose control of their vehicle. In conditions that cause poor traction, a driver should accelerate especially smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Before operating a bus, you should ensure that it is safe by:
questions.answerA: Reviewing the inspection report left by the previous driver.
questions.answerC: Asking your supervisor if the bus seems safe.
questions.answerD: Asking passengers if they are comfortable.
questions.explanation: A bus must always be inspected before it is driven. The inspection process must include a review of the inspection report made by the previous driver. You should operate the vehicle only if defects listed on the inspection report have been certified as repaired or as not needing to be repaired.

questions.question: If a tire rim is damaged, it should be:
questions.answerD: Put on the axle farthest from the driver.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are not safe.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test:
questions.answerA: Points are deducted for each pull-up.
questions.answerB: A driver is allowed three pull-ups per maneuver.
questions.answerC: A pull-up will earn points only if the driver gets out of the vehicle before pulling up.
questions.answerD: Only an excessive number of pull-ups will be counted as errors.
questions.explanation: During the basic vehicle control skills test, there is no penalty for an initial pull-up; however, an excessive number of pull-ups will count as errors.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be secured:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows access to all emergency exits.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers must not leave luggage in doorways or aisles. All items should be secured in a way that allows passengers to exit by any door or window in an emergency.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Is necessary to warm up parts of the engine.
questions.answerC: Is encouraged to improve gas mileage.
questions.answerD: Should be done on surfaces with poor traction.
questions.explanation: Accelerate smoothly and gradually. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: When driving:
questions.answerA: You should always drive at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: You should always drive slightly below the posted speed limit.
questions.answerC: You should adjust your speed according to conditions.
questions.answerD: You should drive as fast as possible.
questions.explanation: Operators driving too fast is a major cause of fatal crashes. You must continually adjust your speed to a rate that is safe for road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerA: Should be used together on all axles.
questions.answerB: Should be used together, but only on the rear axle.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, ensure that radial and bias-ply tires are not being used together.

questions.question: What are placards?
questions.answerA: Signs placed on a vehicle to identify cargo hazards
questions.answerB: A type of tire used in snowy conditions
questions.explanation: Placards are diamond-shaped warning signs that are placed on the outside of vehicles carrying hazardous materials. Placards are used to identify the specific hazard classes of the cargo being carried.

questions.question: Alcohol is removed from the body:
questions.answerA: At a rate that changes depending on how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerB: At a consistent rate, regardless of how much alcohol is in the body.
questions.answerC: More quickly if the person drinks coffee.
questions.answerD: More quickly if the person stays awake.
questions.explanation: The liver removes alcohol from the body at a fixed rate that cannot be accelerated through common tricks, such as drinking coffee or taking a cold shower. The only way to sober up after drinking is to give your body the time it requires to process the alcohol out of your system.

questions.question: A posted speed limit that is safe for cars:
questions.answerA: Is usually safe to be driven by buses.
questions.answerB: May be too fast for a bus.
questions.answerC: May be too slow for a bus.
questions.answerD: Should be thought of as the minimum speed limit.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on roadways, especially through turns and curves, may be safe for cars but too fast for buses. Drivers of large vehicles should be aware of how fast their vehicle can safely be driven.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report, the driver:
questions.answerA: Should not look at the report and instead try to find any issues themselves.
questions.answerB: Should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely only on the report.
questions.explanation: For the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review the last inspection report on your vehicle, if there is one. The carrier should have repaired any problems noted on the report.

questions.question: If your vehicle is equipped with a cargo lift, you should ensure that:
questions.answerD: The lift is the proper color.
questions.explanation: When checking a cargo lift as part of your vehicle inspection test, you should check for leaking, damaged, or missing parts. The lift must be fully retracted and latched securely.

questions.question: Brake pads should:
questions.answerD: Not have any oil or grease on them.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should verify that the shoes and pads do not have any oil, grease, or brake fluid on them.

questions.question: When carrying multiple classes of approved hazardous materials on a bus, no more than a combined total of ____ of the materials may be transported at once.
questions.explanation: Buses may carry no more than 500 total pounds of hazardous materials, including no more than 100 pounds of any one class of material.

questions.question: Windshield wiper blades should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check the wiper blades for damage, stiff rubber, and proper securement. Clean the blades if they are dirty.

questions.question: When checking the power steering fluid during a vehicle inspection, you will need to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Show where the power steering fluid dipstick is located.
questions.answerB: Check for adequate power steering fluid.
questions.answerC: Ensure that the power steering fluid level is above the full mark.
questions.answerD: Ensure that the power steering level is above the refill mark.
questions.explanation: When checking the power steering fluid during the vehicle inspection test, you must be able to indicate where the power steering fluid dipstick is located and show that there is an adequate amount of power steering fluid in the engine compartment. The fluid level must be above the refill mark.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a warning sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Possible warning signs of fatigue include trouble focusing, frequent blinking, or eyelids that feel heavy; repeated yawning; rubbing your eyes; daydreaming, or having wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles; missing exits or traffic signs; trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane, following too closely, or hitting a rumble strip; and feeling restless or irritable.

questions.question: If an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is equipped on a trailer but not on a tractor:
questions.answerA: The truck should not be driven because ABS needs to be on both the tractor and trailer.
questions.answerB: The truck should be driven more slowly than usual.
questions.answerC: The tractor should not be used and a new tractor with ABS should be located.
questions.answerD: The tractor and trailer can still be used together.
questions.explanation: A vehicle being equipped with anti-lock brakes on only the tractor or only the trailer provides additional control during braking.

questions.question: Carry-on bags should be placed:
questions.answerA: In front of the back door.
questions.answerB: In front of the front door.
questions.answerC: In a location that allows easy access to all emergency exits.
questions.explanation: Bus passengers should not be allowed to leave baggage in any doorway or aisle. Baggage and freight must be secured in a manner that will prevent damage, allow the driver to move freely and easily, allow riders to exit by any window or door in an emergency, and protect riders from injury if the items fall or shift.

questions.question: Buses must never carry ____ in the space occupied by passengers.
questions.explanation: Buses must never carry labeled radioactive materials in the area occupied by passengers.

questions.question: An example of mandatory emergency equipment is:
questions.answerA: A supply of spare electrical fuses.
questions.explanation: Mandatory emergency equipment includes: at least one fire extinguisher; spare electrical fuses (unless the vehicle is equipped with circuit breakers); and warning devices for parked vehicles (such as reflective triangles).

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerA: Loosen your grip on the steering wheel.
questions.answerC: Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: In the event of tire failure, hold the steering wheel firmly. Stay off the brakes and let the vehicle slow down on its own. Once the vehicle has slowed considerably, you should brake very gently, pull off the road, and stop. Check your tires after coming to a complete stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good rule to follow when making a turn?
questions.answerB: Use your arms to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.answerC: Turn off your turn signal before entering the turn to avoid confusing other drivers.
questions.explanation: Signal well in advance of a turn so drivers behind you are aware of your intentions. Keep the signal on throughout the turn and turn it off once the turn is complete.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it could cause the wheels to lock.
questions.answerC: You should turn the wheel very sharply.
questions.answerD: You should hold down the brakes until you are past the hazard.
questions.explanation: If you are turning to avoid a hazard, do not apply the brakes while you are turning. This could easily lock the wheels and create a skid.

questions.question: During a trip, which of the following does not need to be checked regularly?
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly monitor the instruments, gauges, meters, and mirrors. Check the tires, cargo, and lights for signs of trouble.

questions.question: What should be used to check for proper tire inflation?
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you must use a tire gauge to check for proper tire inflation. You will not receive passing credit if you simply kick the tires.

questions.question: If pulled over on the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Use the taillights to alert other motorists.
questions.answerC: Keep your lights off to avoid distracting other drivers.
questions.answerD: Set out items from the cab to warn motorists.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you should turn on your emergency flashers and place the appropriate warning signals to warn other drivers.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should be:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are activated, you should never:
questions.answerC: Release air from the air storage tanks.
questions.answerD: Open the door to the cab.
questions.explanation: Never apply the brake pedal if your spring breaks are activated. Brakes can be damaged if they are subject to both springs and air pressure.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerD: Be especially careful because the brakes may fail.
questions.explanation: You should not apply the brake pedal if the spring brakes are activated. The brakes could be damaged if they are subjected to the force of air pressure and the springs at the same time.

questions.question: When only the tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: There is a decreased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerB: There is an increased risk of jackknifing.
questions.answerC: The brakes will not work as effectively as they would without ABS.
questions.answerD: The brakes will become more sensitive.
questions.explanation: If a tractor is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) but the trailer is not, the risk of jackknifing will be reduced and the driver should still be able to maintain steering control. If only the trailer is equipped with ABS, it is less likely that the trailer will swing out to one side.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, a leak in one system:
questions.answerA: Always means there are leaks in both systems.
questions.answerB: May not affect the other system.
questions.answerC: Is not something to worry about.
questions.answerD: Will also affect the other system.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. If there is an air leak in one system, it may not affect the other.

questions.question: How is the parking brake released?
questions.answerA: By tapping the brake pedal three times
questions.answerB: By pushing in the brake control knob
questions.explanation: In vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a knob. The knob is pulled out to apply the brakes, and pushed in to release them.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Each system has separate air tanks, hoses, and lines.
questions.answerB: The systems share air tanks, but each has its own separate hoses and lines.
questions.answerC: Each system uses the same lines and hoses.
questions.answerD: One system is the main braking system and a second system is ready to be used if the first one fails.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: How many air storage tanks are used in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Air storage tanks are used to hold compressed air. The number and size of air tanks in an air brake system varies among vehicles.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you must wait for the air compressor to build a minimum of ____ in both the primary and secondary systems.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for the air compressor to build up at least 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems.

questions.question: In cold weather, an alcohol evaporator should be checked and filled:
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: To confirm that a trailer has ABS, you can:
questions.answerA: Look under the trailer for wheel speed sensors coming from the back of the brakes.
questions.answerB: Look under the hood for the ABS sticker.
questions.answerD: Remove a tire and look for the ABS sensor on the axle.
questions.explanation: If you are unsure if a trailer is equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), look under the vehicle for the electronic control unit and wheel speed sensor wires coming from the back of the brakes.

questions.question: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by:
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS):
questions.answerA: Cannot be used with air brakes.
questions.answerB: Should be used on dry pavement.
questions.answerC: Can assist in maintaining control when braking.
questions.answerD: Should only be used if all axles have ABS.
questions.explanation: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are compatible with air braking systems. ABS helps maintain control of a vehicle and prevents the wheels from locking up during hard braking on slippery surfaces. ABS can still provide benefits even if is present on only one axle.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.answerD: The brakes will be very sensitive.
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out faster than the compressor can replace it, reducing the available air pressure. If the air pressure in an air brake system gets too low, the brakes will no longer work.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pushed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal’s resting position and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop a vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work. On vehicles with hydraulic brakes, the brakes work instantly when the pedal is pressed.

questions.question: If braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add ____ to your vehicle's total stopping distance.
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to a vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a single vehicle with air brakes is:
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: Applying the brake pedal causes air pressure to activate an electric switch and:
questions.answerB: Turn on the low pressure warning light.
questions.answerD: Turn off the low pressure warning light.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: What color is the low air pressure warning light?
questions.explanation: A low air pressure warning signal is required in vehicles with air brakes. The warning light is usually red and may be accompanied by a buzzer.

questions.question: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerC: Push against the inside of the drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: When inspecting your brakes, a slack adjuster should move ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after setting wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: Water and compressor oil are usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. Water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the air brake system.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: What is removed when an air tank is drained?
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow water and compressor oil to be removed. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system.

questions.question: To stop a vehicle using air brakes:
questions.answerA: The brake pedal should be pressed.
questions.answerB: The brake pedal should be lifted.
questions.answerC: The brake knob should be pulled out.
questions.answerD: The brake knob should be pushed in.
questions.explanation: To stop normally in a vehicle with air brakes, press down the brake pedal.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Has a single air brake system, but uses two sets of controls.
questions.answerB: Has one air brake system for each side of the truck.
questions.answerC: Has two brakes for each wheel.
questions.answerD: Has two separate air brake systems, but uses a single set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems that use a single set of brake controls. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles. The other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: Air tank drains:
questions.answerA: Allow rain water to enter the tanks.
questions.answerB: Are used to drain water and oil from the air tanks.
questions.explanation: Compressed air in an air brake system usually contains a certain amount of water and compressor oil. The water and oil can damage the brakes if left to accumulate in the system. Manually operated air tank drains must be opened daily to remove this build-up.

questions.question: Brake fading is caused when:
questions.answerA: Brakes are not used often enough.
questions.explanation: Using the brakes excessively will cause them to overheat, making them less effective. This is referred to as "fading."

questions.question: A tank endorsement is:
questions.answerC: Required to transport both liquids and gases.
questions.explanation: Subject to certain conditions, a tank endorsement is required to operate a tank vehicle that is used to haul either liquids or gases.

questions.question: On a truck with air brakes, the braking system’s air compressor:
questions.answerA: Pumps air into the air storage tanks.
questions.answerC: Moves air to the back of the truck.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air compressor pumps air into the air storage tanks. The air compressor is controlled by the air compressor governor.

questions.question: An air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately ____ to come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: To ensure normal stopping power, drivers of vehicles equipped with a front brake limiting valve should:
questions.answerB: Set the control to the off position.
questions.answerD: Keep the control at the halfway mark.
questions.explanation: Some pre-1975 vehicles have a front brake limiting valve, which has "normal" and "slippery" settings. The idea behind these valves was to limit the air pressure available to the front brakes when driving on slippery surfaces, and thereby reduce the danger of a front-wheel skid. Studies have found that this is not actually a concern, so if your vehicle has a front brake limiting valve, leave it in the "normal" position.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, the maximum leakage rate for a double combination vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: To stop in a vehicle that uses air brakes, the driver should:
questions.explanation: To make a normal stop in a vehicle with air brakes, push the brake pedal down. The harder the pedal is pressed, the more air pressure is released.

questions.question: To use the stab braking method in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the brakes completely until the wheels lock up, release the brakes until the wheels start rolling, then repeat the process.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes about halfway, but keep the wheels rolling.
questions.answerC: Fully apply the brakes, let the wheels lock up, and hold the brake pedal down, keeping the wheels locked until the vehicle stops.
questions.explanation: The stab braking method for emergency stops involves fully applying the brakes until they lock up. The brakes are then released until the wheels start rolling, then the process is repeated.

questions.question: Pressing and releasing a brake pedal unnecessarily can:
questions.answerA: Release air faster than it can be replaced.
questions.answerB: Add more air to the braking system.
questions.answerC: Make the brake pedal more sensitive.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can release air from the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it.

questions.question: The application pressure gauge:
questions.answerA: Shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes.
questions.answerB: Shows the temperature of air being used in the braking system.
questions.answerC: Shows the pressure of the air coming from the compressor.
questions.answerD: Shows the number of times the brakes have been used.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the application pressure gauge shows how much air pressure is being applied to the brakes. Not all vehicles with an air brake system have this gauge.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes that were built on or after March 1, 1997 are equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes that were manufactured on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS). ABS is required in any other type of vehicle with air brakes that was manufactured on or after March 1, 1998.

questions.question: During a walk-around inspection, ensure there are no cracks on the brake drums that are more than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: The parking brake should be:
questions.answerA: Used whenever you park the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Set when driving in bad weather.
questions.answerD: Used to stop the vehicle in normal driving.
questions.explanation: The parking brake should be applied every time you park your vehicle.

questions.question: The emergency brake system uses:
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system.
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system.
questions.answerC: Parts of both the parking and service brake systems.
questions.answerD: Only parts unique to the emergency brake system.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: If the air pressure warning light comes on, you should:
questions.answerB: Activate your hazard lights and continue driving.
questions.answerC: Call the local law enforcement agency.
questions.answerD: Safely exit the roadway and stop.
questions.explanation: If the air pressure warning light or buzzer comes on while you are driving, you should immediately stop and safely park the vehicle. This warning signal indicates that there is a problem in the air brake system that needs to be fixed.

questions.question: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when:
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with air brakes, you should ensure that the spring brakes come on automatically when air tank pressure falls to a level between 20 and 45 psi. You can do this by chocking the wheels and releasing air from the braking system by stepping on and off the brake pedal. Once the pressure drops to an unsafe level, the parking brake valve should pop out and spring brakes should come on.

questions.question: If the low pressure warning light comes on while you are driving:
questions.answerA: Braking will only be possible if there is still enough air in the tanks.
questions.answerB: You can apply the brakes 14 times before the air in the system runs out.
questions.answerC: You should continue to drive normally and check the brake system when it is convenient.
questions.answerD: You should stay at least 100 feet away from other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving a vehicle with air brakes, if the low air pressure warning light comes on, it is important for you to stop and safely park your vehicle as soon as possible. There may be a leak in the system. Controlled braking will remain possible only as long as there is enough air left in the tanks.

questions.question: If a vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. In what condition should the belt be?
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with air brakes that has a belt-driven air compressor, you should check the condition and tightness of the belt. It should be in good condition.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerA: Regularly to activate the trailer brakes in all driving conditions.
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Only in inclement weather when the trailer may skid.
questions.answerD: Only if the trailer is carrying a load.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve should be used only to test the trailer brakes. It should not be used while driving because it may cause the trailer to skid.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: Which type of vehicle is most prone to the “crack-the-whip” effect?
questions.explanation: Triple combination trailers are most vulnerable to the "crack-the-whip" effect.

questions.question: After finishing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Leave the rear shut-off valves open.
questions.answerD: Leave the emergency line valve open.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should ensure that air reaches all air brakes on all trailers by opening up the rear emergency line and service line shut-off valves to listen for escaping air. Close both shut-off valves before beginning to drive.

questions.question: Emergency air lines are often coded with the color:
questions.explanation: In general, the parts of the service air line are coded blue and the parts of the emergency air line are coded red.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out when:
questions.answerA: Air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi.
questions.answerB: You are experiencing a trailer jackknife.
questions.answerC: Wheels have regained traction after a skid.
questions.explanation: In vehicles equipped with an automatic tractor protection valve, the valve will pop out if air pressure drops to a level between 20 and 45 psi. When the valve pops out, the protection valve will close, stopping the flow of air.

questions.question: Rollovers happen when drivers:
questions.explanation: A rollover happens as a result of a driver taking a turn at too high a speed. Be sure to take turns and curves safely and slowly.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: Test the tractor protection valve by:
questions.answerB: Removing the parking brake control knob.
questions.answerC: Releasing air with the brake pedal.
questions.answerD: Releasing air with the gas pedal.
questions.explanation: You should test the tractor protection valve by allowing the air supply to properly charge, turning off the engine, then releasing air from the system by pressing the brake pedal several times. The tractor protection valve should move into its emergency position when psi drops to an unsafe level.

questions.question: When lightly loaded, combination vehicles:
questions.answerD: Should be loaded with most of the weight in the rear of the trailer.
questions.explanation: When a combination vehicle is lightly loaded, it may have poor traction. It is very easy for wheels to lock up on lightly-loaded vehicles when they are being stopped.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should:
questions.answerB: Be used only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.answerC: Be used together with the brake pedal.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve works the trailer brakes but should only be used when testing them. Using it while driving could create a skid. Never use the trailer hand valve while parking because doing so may release the air pressure from the braking system, releasing the brakes that are holding the vehicle in place.

questions.question: If your trailer begins to drift off course while you are backing, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue trying to back up without stopping.
questions.answerB: Turn the top of your steering wheel in the direction of the drift.
questions.answerC: Turn the top of the steering wheel in the direction opposite of the drift.
questions.answerD: Return the steering wheel to the 12 o’clock position.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to drift while you are backing, you should correct the drift immediately by turning the top of the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: If oil and water build up in your vehicle's air tanks, the brakes:
questions.explanation: Air tanks should be drained daily to remove water and oil buildup. An excess of oil and water in the air tanks can interfere with proper brake function.

questions.question: Large combination vehicles take the longest amount of time to stop:
questions.explanation: Large combination vehicles take longer to stop when they are empty than when they are loaded. The decreased weight causes a vehicle's wheels to have decreased traction on the surface of the road.

questions.question: Simply changing lanes can cause:
questions.answerA: A “crack-the-whip” effect, resulting in a rollover.
questions.answerC: Confusion over which lane the driver is hoping to use.
questions.answerD: Other drivers to reduce their speed.
questions.explanation: Due to the "crack-the-whip" effect caused by rearward amplification, changing lanes too quickly in a combination vehicle can result in a rollover.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: Only to test the trailer brakes.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes. Using it while a vehicle is in motion could cause a skid.

questions.question: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and:
questions.answerA: Detach the jaws from around the kingpin.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking lever is in the "emergency" position.
questions.answerD: Look into the back of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: While inspecting a coupling, you should go under the trailer and look into the back of the fifth wheel. Ensure that the fifth wheel jaws are secured around the shank of the kingpin.

questions.question: How many air lines does a combination vehicle have?
questions.explanation: Every combination vehicle has two air lines: the service line and the emergency line.

questions.question: Before backing your tractor under the trailer, make sure your trailer brakes are:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. Before backing your tractor under the trailer while coupling, make sure your trailer brakes are locked.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.answerD: To test the lights on the trailer.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve, also called the trolley valve or Johnson bar, is used to work the trailer brakes. It should be used only to test the brakes.

questions.question: To lower the risk of a rollover, you should:
questions.answerA: Load the cargo as far forward as possible.
questions.answerB: Load the cargo as far back as possible.
questions.answerC: Load the cargo as low as possible.
questions.answerD: Stack the cargo as high as possible.
questions.explanation: To lower the risk of a rollover, load your cargo as closely to the ground as possible. To further reduce this risk, take curves and corners slowly.

questions.question: If the trailer begins to skid, it is best to:
questions.answerC: Quickly turn the steering wheel one way, then the other.
questions.explanation: If your trailer begins to skid, you should release the brakes to help regain traction. Once the wheels grip the road again, the trailer will begin to straighten out and follow the path of the tractor.

questions.question: When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that you:
questions.answerB: Make sure there is a large enough gap for your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Expect other drivers to make room for your vehicle.
questions.answerD: Let other drivers wave you into their lane.
questions.explanation: Combination vehicles require more space on the road than other vehicles. When entering or crossing traffic while driving a combination vehicle, it is especially important that there is a large enough gap in traffic for you to safely do so.

questions.question: A shut-off valve:
questions.answerA: Is located on the front of a trailer.
questions.answerB: Is located on the instrument panel.
questions.answerC: Prevents air from escaping an air brake system.
questions.explanation: Shut-off valves are used in air supply lines to control the passage of air from one trailer to another. The rear shut-off valve should always be closed to prevent air from leaving the braking system.

questions.question: The best way to recognize that your trailer has begun to skid is by:
questions.explanation: The earliest and best way to recognize the beginnings of a trailer skid is by seeing the trailer veer off-course in your mirrors.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line is also referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: What is another name for the service line?
questions.explanation: The trailer service air line may also be referred to as the control line or signal line.

questions.question: During a trip, which shut-off valves should be open?
questions.answerA: All shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerB: The rear shut-off valves should be open.
questions.answerC: All shut-off valves should be in the open position, except the rear shut-off valves.
questions.answerD: No shut-off valves should be open.
questions.explanation: When starting a trip, be sure that all shut-off valves are in the open position, except for the last valves on the rear trailer. It is important that air reaches the brakes on all trailers and that the air is not able to escape from the back of the vehicle.

questions.question: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be:
questions.answerA: Slightly higher than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerB: Level with the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerC: Slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.answerD: Next to the center of the fifth wheel.
questions.explanation: When connecting a converter dolly to a second or third trailer, the trailer height should be correct. It should be slightly lower than the center of the fifth wheel.

questions.question: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly greased could:
questions.explanation: Failure to keep the fifth wheel plate properly lubricated can create friction between the tractor and trailer, causing steering problems.

questions.question: Trailers with low underneath clearance may be difficult to drive:
questions.explanation: Railroad-highway crossings may be difficult to cross when pulling a trailer with a low underneath clearance. In particular, both low-slung units and single-axle tractors pulling long trailers are especially challenging to drive over raised crossings.

questions.question: When coupling a trailer:
questions.answerA: Make sure to couple matching glad hands.
questions.answerB: Any glad hand can be connected to any other glad hand.
questions.answerC: It is best to leave one glad hand unattached.
questions.answerD: Only one set of glad hands should be connected.
questions.explanation: When coupling, make sure you couple matching glad hands. They are often color-coded to help drivers avoid mistakes. Typically, blue is used for service lines and red is used for emergency lines.

questions.question: When driving a bobtail tractor, you should be aware that:
questions.answerB: Bobtails cannot drive as fast as tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerC: Bobtails are more difficult to stop than tractors with semitrailers.
questions.answerD: Bobtails are illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to bring the bobtail to a complete stop than it would a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: How many air lines does a combination vehicle have?
questions.explanation: Every combination vehicle has two air lines: the service line and the emergency line.

questions.question: After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should:
questions.explanation: Correctly following the steps to couple and uncouple trailers is vital to safely operating a combination vehicle. After connecting the air lines to the trailer while coupling, you should supply air to the trailer.

questions.question: In a double or triple combination:
questions.answerA: Cargo weight must be evenly distributed between all trailers.
questions.answerB: The heaviest trailer should be positioned directly behind the cab.
questions.answerC: The heaviest trailer should be positioned in the rear.
questions.answerD: The weight of the trailers does not matter.
questions.explanation: When positioning trailers in a combination, the most heavily-loaded trailer should be the closest to the tractor. The lightest trailer should be positioned in the rear.

questions.question: What does the tractor protection valve do?
questions.answerA: Protects the tractor from being stolen
questions.answerB: Protects the tractor from exceeding a set speed
questions.answerC: Keeps air in the braking system, should the trailer break away or develop a leak
questions.answerD: Ensures oil adequately lubricates the engine
questions.explanation: The tractor protection valve keeps air in the tractor or truck braking system, should the trailer break away or develop a bad leak.

questions.question: If a load is placed on one side of a trailer, the trailer:
questions.answerA: May lean, and could result in a rollover.
questions.answerB: May add extra support during turns.
questions.explanation: If the weight of a load is placed primarily one side of a trailer, the trailer may lean, increasing the risk of a rollover.

questions.question: Before a drive, ensure that air flows to all trailers by:
questions.answerA: Opening the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerB: Closing the rear shut-off valves and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerC: Disconnecting air supply lines and listening for escaping air.
questions.answerD: Rolling each trailer down a hill and testing the brakes.
questions.explanation: Before a trip, ensure that air in the air brake system reaches all trailers. Do this by waiting for air pressure to build, then sending air to both the emergency and service lines and opening the shut-off valves on the rear of the last trailer. If air escapes from the shut-off valves in the rear of the combination, the air is being supplied to the entire vehicle.

questions.question: When driving a combination rig, following distance should be:
questions.answerB: Shorter than when driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerC: About the same as when driving a single vehicle.
questions.answerD: Longer than when driving a single vehicle.
questions.explanation: In comparison to driving a single vehicle, you should maintain an extended following distance when driving a combination rig. Combinations require longer stopping distances than smaller vehicles.
